form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Sanders introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance

form.official-title: To require every employer to provide to their employees a retirement program with benefits equivalent to the Federal Employees Retirement System or to elect for their employees to participate in the Federal Employees Retirement System, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Pensions for All Act.

paragraph.text: The term covered retirement program means a retirement program other than FERS that the Secretary determines provides benefits that are comparable to the benefits available under FERS to an employee (as that term is defined under section 8401 of title 5, United States Code, on the day before the date of enactment of this Act).
The terms employer and employee have the meanings given such terms in section 3 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (29 U.S.C. 1002).
The term FERS means the Federal Employees Retirement System under chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code.
The term Secretary means the Secretary of Labor.

section.header: Requirement to provide a retirement plan equivalent to FERS or to participate in FERS

paragraph.text: Each employer shall—

subparagraph.text: make available to each employee employed by the employer a covered retirement program; or
notify the Secretary that the employees of the employer will participate in FERS.

paragraph.text: Each self-employed individual shall—

subparagraph.text: be enrolled in a covered retirement program; or
notify the Secretary that the self-employed individual will participate in FERS.

paragraph.text: At a frequency determined by the Secretary, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, that is not less than annually, an employer that has in effect a covered retirement program for the employees of the employer or with respect to whom the employees of the employer are participating in FERS may elect to—

subparagraph.text: in the case of an employer that has in effect a covered retirement program—

clause.text: cease making contributions to the covered retirement program for such employees; and
have each employee employed by the employer participate in FERS; or

subparagraph.text: in the case of an employer with respect to whom the employees of the employer are participating in FERS—

clause.text: have the employees cease participating in FERS; and
make available to each employee employed by the employer a covered retirement program.

paragraph.text: At a frequency determined by the Secretary, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, that is not less than annually, a self-employed individual who is enrolled in a covered retirement program or is participating in FERS may elect to—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a self-employed individual who is enrolled in a covered retirement program—

clause.text: cease making contributions to the covered retirement program; and
participate in FERS; or

subparagraph.text: in the case of a self-employed individual who is participating in FERS—

clause.text: cease participating in FERS; and
enroll in a covered retirement program.

section.header: Credit for small employer and self-employed pension contributions

subsection.text: Subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting after section 36 the following new section:

section.header: Credit for small employer and self-employed pension contributions

subsection.text: In the case of an eligible taxpayer, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax imposed by subtitle A an amount equal to the contribution assistance amount with respect to such taxpayer for the taxable year.
In the case of an eligible taxpayer, for purposes of this section—

paragraph.text: The contribution assistance amount is an amount equal to the applicable percentage of the qualified pension contributions paid by the eligible taxpayer during the taxable year.
For purposes of paragraph (1), the applicable percentage is 50 percent, reduced (but not below zero) by the number of percentage points which—

subparagraph.text: in the case of an employer, bears the same ratio to 50 as the excess of—

clause.text: the gross receipts of the employer for the taxable year, over

subparagraph.text: in the case of a self-employed individual, bears the same ratio to 50 as the excess of—

clause.text: the income of the individual for the taxable year, over
$75,000, bears to

paragraph.text: The term qualified pension contributions means—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a covered non-Federal employer or covered self-employed individual, the contributions made by such employer or individual under sections 8423(a) and 8432(c) of title 5, United States Code,

in the case of any other employer, the nonelective contributions made by such employer to a covered retirement program (as defined in section 2 of the Pensions for All Act) on behalf of the employees of the employer, and
in the case of any other self-employed individual, the contributions made by such individual to a covered retirement program (as so defined) of the individual.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section—

paragraph.text: The term eligible taxpayer means—

subparagraph.text: any covered non-Federal employer making an election under both sections 8423(a)(4)(E)(i) and 8432(c)(4)(E)(i) of title 5, United States Code not to receive a reduction in employer contributions,
any employer which is not a covered non-Federal employer,
any covered self-employed individual making an election under both sections 8423(a)(4)(E)(ii) and 8432(c)(4)(E)(ii) of title 5, United States Code not to receive a reduction in contributions, and
any self-employed individual who is not a covered self-employed individual.

paragraph.header: Covered non-Federal employer; covered self-employed individual
paragraph.text: The terms covered non-Federal employer and covered self-employed individual have the respective meanings given such terms by section 8401 of title 5, United States Code.

paragraph.header: Business credit treated as part of general business credit
paragraph.text: In the case of an employer, the credit which (but for this paragraph) would otherwise be allowed under subsection (a) for any taxable year shall be treated as a credit listed in section 38(b) for such taxable year (and not allowed under subsection (a)).

No deduction or credit shall be allowed under any other section of this title with respect to contributions to a plan (including the Federal Employees Retirement System under chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code) if credit is allowable with respect to such contributions under subsection (a) (determined without regard to this subsection).

section.header: Failure to provide covered retirement program

subsection.text: Chapter 43 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

section.header: Failure to maintain required retirement program

paragraph.text: There is hereby imposed a tax on the failure of an employer either—

subparagraph.text: to make available a covered retirement program to all employees of the employer, or
in the case of a covered employer, to make required contributions under sections 8423(a) and 8432(c) of title 5, United States Code with respect to the employees of the employer.

paragraph.text: There is hereby imposed a tax on the failure of a self-employed individual either—

subparagraph.text: to participate in a covered retirement program, or
in the case of a covered self-employed individual, to make required contributions under sections 8423(a) and 8432(c) of title 5, United States Code with respect to the individual.

paragraph.text: The amount of the tax imposed by subsection (a) on any failure with respect to an employee or self-employed individual shall be $10 for each day in the noncompliance period with respect to such failure.
For purposes of this section, the term noncompliance period means, with respect to any failure, the period—

subparagraph.text: beginning on the date such failure first occurs, and
ending on the earlier of—

clause.text: the date such failure is corrected, or
with respect to any employer, the date that is 3 months after the last date on which the employee is employed by the employer.

subparagraph.text: In the case of any failure occurring in a calendar year beginning after 2026, the $10 amount under paragraph (1) shall be increased by an amount equal to such dollar amount multiplied by the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year determined by substituting calendar year 2025 for calendar year 2016 in subparagraph (A)(ii) thereof.
If any amount adjusted under subparagraph (A) is not a whole dollar amount, such amount shall be rounded to the nearest whole dollar amount.

paragraph.header: Tax not to apply where failure not discovered exercising reasonable diligence
paragraph.text: No tax shall be imposed by subsection (a) on any failure during any period for which it is established to the satisfaction of the Secretary that none of the persons referred to in subsection (d) knew, nor exercising reasonable diligence would have known, that such failure existed.
In the case of failures which are due to reasonable cause and not to willful neglect—

subparagraph.text: The tax imposed by subsection (a) for failures during the taxable year of the employer or self-employed individual shall not exceed $500,000.

subparagraph.header: Taxable years in the case of certain controlled groups
subparagraph.text: For purposes of this subparagraph, if not all persons who are treated as a single employer for purposes of this section have the same taxable year, the taxable years taken into account shall be determined under principles similar to the principles of section 1561.

paragraph.text: In the case of a failure which is due to reasonable cause and not to willful neglect, the Secretary may waive part or all of the tax imposed by subsection (a) to the extent that the payment of such tax would be excessive relative to the failure involved.

subsection.text: The employer shall be liable for the tax imposed by subsection (a)(1) on a failure. All employers, determined without regard to subsection (e)(2), shall be jointly and severally liable for the liability of any other employer with which they are aggregated under subsection (e)(2).
For purposes of this section—

paragraph.header: Terms relating to covered retirement programs, etc
paragraph.text: Any term used in this section which is defined in section 2 of the Pensions for All Act has the meaning given such term by such section.
All employers treated as a single employer under subsection (b), (c), (m), or (o) of section 414 shall be treated as 1 employer.

subsection.text: The table of sections for chapter 43 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 4980J. Failure to maintain required retirement program.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to plan years beginning after December 31, 2025.

section.header: Prohibition on the reduction of compensation
section.text: An employer that employs an employee on or before the date of enactment of this Act may not reduce any form of compensation provided to the employee due to the requirement imposed by this Act that the employee be enrolled in a covered retirement program or FERS.
